 I'm a bit curious what a "natural eunuch" might be. Certainly there are men born with no testicles, but that's quite rare. Hardly seems like something that would occur often enough to be addressed in Roman law. Maybe it refers to undescended testicles -- somewhat more common -- or impotent men (which would include a lot of gay men, I suppose... impotent with women, that is). 
 
 Logically, I would guess it would mean sterile men, but the Romans, like most male-dominated societies, would probably have blamed women in all cases of couple infertility.
 
 As for what sort of proof you need, biblical scholars routinely scour contemporary sources to figure out what the bible is talking about. It's not like there's an appendix at the end to describe all the terms used.
